item.title: Anker 14-Port Docking Station Gets a Black Friday Price Tag Despite Being a New Release, but Only a Few Units Exist
item.content:encoded:
Most of us rely on multiple devices to get through the day. These are great to stay productive, but things can often get a little messy on the connectivity side. Before you know, you‚Äôre dealing with a whole bunch of cables and adapters on your desk; not a good sight.

If you‚Äôre looking to make your workstation cleaner and more efficient, investing in a docking station can be a smart choice. These tiny but mighty devices serve as a connectivity hub, letting you add multiple external peripherals at the same time, plus charge your essentials as well. Today is a great time to pick a top-rated option, as Amazon‚Äôs early Black Friday sale has dropped the price of the 14-port Anker Prime Docking Station by 30%. It‚Äôs now available for just $210, after a whopping $90 discount. The deal applies to the gray color option and is open to all shoppers. The black version is going for $272 (down from $340), but the discount is exclusive to Prime members on that one. Note that most early deals wrap up before the event, which means this one is only around for a limited time. It‚Äôs best to grab it sooner rather than later.

See at Amazon

Multiple Ports for Multiple Essentials

Anker has packed this docking station with 14 ports in total. You‚Äôre getting a 140W 10Gbps USB-C upstream port, two 100W 10Gbps USB-C ports, one 100W 5Gbps USB-C port, two HDMI ports, one DisplayPort, two 5Gbps USB-A ports, one 480Mbps USB-A port, a 2.5Gbps Ethernet port, a headphone and mic combo jack, and SD and TF card slots. That‚Äôs enough to add all your essentials without feeling limited. Think mouse, keyboard, laptop, external monitors, headphones, external storage, and more.

The three USB-C ports at the front support both charging and data transfer. You can juice your laptop up with up to 140W via the upstream port, and use the rest to charge other devices. The full 140W power can be achieved when you only have the laptop connected at the front. The two HDMI and DisplayPort let you add up to three external monitors to your setup simultaneously, including one in 8K.

The station is compatible with both macOS 13.5 or later and Windows 10/11, but you will need to install the latest DisplayLink driver if you want to add more screens to the setup. It‚Äôs not that complicated, as all that you need to do is head over to the Anker website, find the DisplayLink installer that matches your system, and proceed with the download. Just make sure to uninstall any older versions of the driver already on your system, and then follow the on-screen instructions to complete the process. macOS users will also need to enable screen recording and allow the driver to launch automatically after login to proceed.

The process shouldn‚Äôt take more than a few minutes, and once it‚Äôs done, you can enjoy multitasking on a bigger setup. Take video calls on one screen and present using the other. Or work on your main display, while having reference material and relevant documents open on the others! The possibilities are endless.

There‚Äôs also a smart display on the front, just above the USB-C ports. It provides real-time updates on charging power, display performance, and other settings. Anker has even included a built-in fan paired with ActiveShield 3.0 to keep things cool as the docking station works. The box comes with the docking station itself, USB-C to USB-C 3.2 Gen 2 cable for upstream port (3.3 ft, 10 Gbps), 6ft AC power cord, safety sheet with user manual, and a 24-month warranty for some extra peace of mind.

Get your orders in fast, before Amazon decides to shoot the price back up to the not-so-friendly $300.

See at Amazon



https://kotaku.com/anker-14-port-docking-station-gets-a-black-friday-price-tag-despite-being-a-new-release-2000645832

item.title: Roblox CEO Makes Utter Fool Of Himself In Car-Crash Interview Over Child Safety
item.content:encoded:
As ‚Äúpedophile hellscape‚Äù Roblox finally adds a rudimentary measure to try to prevent children from being exploited via its network of games and chatrooms used by 151 million people, the company‚Äôs CEO spoke to the New York Times podcast Hard Fork about child safety. And it didn‚Äôt go great. It really didn‚Äôt go great.

Roblox is coming under increasing scrutiny after decades of failing to implement even the most basic of protective measures to keep its pre-teen players away from the networks of pedophiles who use the game to find victims. Described last year as ‚Äúa pedophile hellscape for kids‚Äù by Hindenburg Research, the game quickly introduced a new assortment of measures last October that did next to nothing, leading this year to a great deal of legal interest. Three months back, the state of Louisiana announced its intentions to sue Roblox for the dangers it was allowing, joined since by Kentucky and Texas. These actions come alongside 35 other ongoing lawsuits, including one from only yesterday by a family in Cuyaho County following Roblox‚Äòs alleged use in the tragic and too common abuse of their 13-year-old son.

On Wednesday of this week, Roblox announced it was beginning to roll out a new method of checking player ages before they could access chat, this time using facial recognition to try to restrict players to only talking to others in their age range. Such facial ID checks have become commonplace in the UK following the disastrously poor UK Online Safety Act, by which porn sites and other age-restricted outlets are required to verify users‚Äô ages. This has led to sites like X, Bluesky and Discord also requiring British users to prove their age, usually by showing their face on camera in a measure that entirely thwarts all seven people who haven‚Äôt heard of a VPN.

Regarding this rollout, the New York Times‚Äò Casey Newton spoke to Roblox co-founder and CEO David Baszucki about the new plans, and whether they can really help. It doesn‚Äôt begin well. When asked about the ‚Äúscope of the problem‚Äù of predators in the application, Baszucki came in shoulders first saying, ‚ÄúWe think of it not necessarily just as a problem, but an opportunity as well.‚Äù Ah, the good ol‚Äô opportunities available when your company‚Äôs product is rife with pedophilia. He continued, outlining how wonderful it is that young people can build and communicate together, how they have ‚Äú150 million daily actives, 11 billion hours a month, like what is the best way to keep pushing this forward.‚Äù It is the most astonishingly tone-deaf response.

Newton attempts to get some sensible answers from Baszucki about how the ID checks will work, and why they won‚Äôt be as easily evaded as so many others, and amidst Baszucki‚Äôs corporate waffle he‚Äôs told that Roblox is apparently always looking out for ‚Äúweird signals‚Äù and will ask for further age verification should these appear, although he didn‚Äôt explain what those signals might be, nor what these further checks would be. But then Newton goes on to ask the painfully necessary question: why has it taken 19 years to even try to stop adults from being able to speak to children?

Baszucki responds by talking about the evolution of Roblox‚Äòs text filtering tech for inappropriate language and personally identifying information over the last two decades, and how it‚Äôs always improving, which is great but clearly not relevant to the question. Newton is having none of it, responding, ‚ÄúYeah, I mean, I don‚Äôt know. When I read these lawsuits and these investigations into the company, it does not seem like predators are having that hard of a time getting around your filters‚Ä¶So I‚Äôm curious what‚Äôs made you so confident that things are working?‚Äù Baszucki‚Äôs response is incoherent.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to comment on it. We do see the chat logs of those. And we can see interesting and, many times, ways of people trying to‚ÄîI‚Äôd say, many times people who are fairly sophisticated, and I‚Äôm not going to say all of them, many times kids who are over 13, who actually in any other app are not running in a filtered situation, unfortunately, figuring out how to jump to some other platform where they can communicate unfiltered, where they can share images, all of it. It‚Äôs one of the primary things we‚Äôre doing is trying to keep people on our platform. It‚Äôs an interesting industry situation. I would say, we‚Äôre not waiting for the rest of the industry. We‚Äôre like, we‚Äôre always trying to stay ahead of it. On the California age-appropriate design code, for example, we‚Äôre like, we are already doing all of that stuff. And the same thing with age estimation: We‚Äôre not doing this because of any laws that are coming, we think it‚Äôs the right thing to do.‚Äù

Newton very impressively keeps his cool, and rather than pointing out that this answer had nothing to do with the situation, nor indeed how unbelievable it is that the CEO of the company would say ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to comment on it‚Äù when asked why he‚Äôs confident in age tech that clearly doesn‚Äôt work, he instead points out that the lawsuits are demonstrating that ‚ÄúRoblox is kind of, you know, where predators go to find kids.‚Äù

Things become increasingly tense, as Baszucki tries to claim this is a misrepresentation, and when pressed on whether he truly doesn‚Äôt believe Roblox has a predator problem replies, ‚ÄúI think we‚Äôre doing an incredible job at innovating relative to the number of people on our platform and the hours, in really leaning in to the future of how this is going to work.‚Äù

What becomes so grimly apparent is that even now, even after a year of extraordinary scrutiny and legal pressure, Baszucki still doesn‚Äôt have a grip on the situation at all. To be so ill-prepared for such obvious questions, to have no coherent responses for why the new tech will be effective, and to go so out of his way to appear so uninterested in the subject, is astonishing. As he‚Äôs pressed further on the ease with which predators can suggest children speak to them on another platform, Baszucki eventually unravels into literal gibberish:

‚ÄúI would actually say that is a very simple red flag. Like, that sounds like text filter many prior generations. So I would say the techniques are much more sophisticated than that. We‚Äôre constantly getting better than that and sometimes it‚Äôs adversarial. Like, we‚Äôre getting into, you know, if we cryptographically were going to try to have an exchange of how to share your Snap handle or whatever handle. We see some of that starting, like things we‚Äôll have to essentially prevent in the future.‚Äù

The CEO seems to believe that the scale of Roblox is somehow an excuse to justify its problems, repeatedly coming back to its 150 million users and 11 billion hours a month, as if this explains it all away. But more problematically, as Newton points out that the company wants those numbers to grow, Baszucki immediately switches back to talking about what an amazing financial opportunity this is. Given Roblox is really struggling to turn those users into money, it reads like he‚Äôs only speaking to investors and analysts who are increasingly concerned about Roblox‚Äòs lack of profits. So many responses begin with an infuriatingly irrelevant attempt to avoid the question, and then end with words like ‚ÄúAnd you could imagine Roblox at 20-X this scale, having 50 percent of the gaming market space all in a single place.‚Äù It‚Äôs so crass!

But not nearly as crass as Baszucki‚Äôs response to a question over the Hindenburg Research report into the scale of the issue with pedophiles. Hindenburg was an activist short-selling research firm that would investigate companies for fraud, malfeasance and indeed rampant use by predators, until its creator chose to disband the group in January this year. At the time of the report, Baszucki said that it was wrong to claim that Roblox had reduced its spend on trust and safety, so Newton asked for specifics.

‚ÄúFun,‚Äù says Baszucki, a man who appears pathologically incapable of reading the room. ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs keep going down this. And so, first off, Hindenburg is not longer in existence, correct? So, you should report on that. They went out of business for some reason‚Ä¶‚Äù He then demanded to know if Newton had researched the answer for himself, before saying that it‚Äôs because they‚Äôve moved so much of the safety regulation onto AI, all while sounding absolutely furious that he was being asked. He then demands that Newton agree that if AI is more effective, it‚Äôs better to use it, and when Newton does, Baszucki starts to behave incredibly immaturely. ‚ÄúGood, so you‚Äôre aligning with what we did. High-five.‚Äù Then when Newton tries to ask a question, he interrupts to say, ‚ÄúThank you for supporting our Roblox decision matrix.‚Äù Then interrupts yet again to say, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm so glad you guys are aligned with the way we run Roblox. High-five.‚Äù Think he‚Äôs done? Nope. Yet again he interrupts the question with, ‚ÄúIs this a stealth interview where actually you love everything we‚Äôre doing and you‚Äôre here to stealthily support it?‚Äù

And he doesn‚Äôt stop. When co-host Kevin Roose tried to get things back on the rails, Baszucki kept going with the same pathetic line. Challenged on how AI has proved very ineffective for social media companies, he just carries on saying it. The only thing that stopped this tantrum was allowing the CEO to talk about Polymarket, a cryptoscam-based prediction market, letting people place bets on things as ridiculous as awards ceremonies and future weather patterns. Some believe it‚Äôs becoming a useful way to predict markets, and that group includes Baszucki who is‚Ä¶and I cannot believe I‚Äôm typing this‚Ä¶looking to put it into Roblox so children can gamble.

He wants to find a way to do this that‚Äôs ‚Äúlegal‚Äù and ‚Äúeducational,‚Äù at which point the podcast hosts begin openly mocking the stupidity. And then, thank god, they run out of time.



https://kotaku.com/roblox-new-york-times-interview-baszucki-2000646174

item.title: Alienware Aurora 16 Gaming Laptop With RTX 5050 GPU Gets Cleared Out at an All-Time Low for Black Friday
item.content:encoded:
In recent years, handheld gaming PCs have become increasingly popular, with devices like the Steam Deck leading the charge. Following its success, models such as the Lenovo Legion Go and Asus ROG Ally have also gained attention. These portable systems offer the ability to play PC games on the go without the bulk of a laptop. However, despite their appeal, handheld gaming PCs remain focused primarily on gaming, and lacking the versatility needed for everyday tasks. If you‚Äôre after a device that can handle both gaming and traditional computer tasks, a gaming laptop is still a better option. Right now, Amazon is offering a great deal on the Alienware 16 Aurora gaming laptop, dropping its price from $1,250 to $900, a savings of $350.

See at Amazon

Optimized for Gaming

The Alienware 16 Aurora is a solid gaming laptop at this discounted price point. It features a 16-inch display with a 16:10 aspect ratio, delivering QHD resolution of 2560 x 1600 pixels. Its 300 nits of brightness and anti-glare coating make it usable even in harsh lighting conditions, like if the sun is peaking through into the room midday. The screen‚Äôs refresh rate peaks at 120Hz, which is great for fast-paced or competitive games. Additionally, the laptop supports. The slim bezels around the display offer more screen space while keeping the overall laptop size manageable.

As for the keyboard, the Alienware 16 Aurora comes with a full-size layout, including a number pad, which is becoming less common in modern laptops.

Inside, the Alienware 16 Aurora is powered by an Intel Core 7 240H processor and an NVIDIA GeForce RTX 5050 laptop GPU, paired with 16GB of RAM and a 1TBGB PCIe Gen4 SSD. It has two upgradable PCIe Gen 4 SSD slots and two upgradable DDR SO-DIMM memory slots if you want to push the current memory and storage even further. While it might not run every AAA game on ultra settings, it‚Äôs a strong performer for the price. Indie titles will run effortlessly, and most larger games should perform well at medium settings, balancing quality and performance.

Looking along the side of the laptop, we have an array of useful ports. It contains two USB-C ports capable of data transfer, device charging, and can be used to display onto an additional monitor. On that same note, an HDMI 2.1 port is found on the backside as well. There‚Äôs also two USB-A 3.2 Gen 1 ports as well as a global headset jack so you can connect a microphone, headphones, or a combination of the two.

At just $900, the Alienware 16 Aurora offers a solid mix of gaming performance and everyday usability. It provides more flexibility than a handheld gaming device, all while maintaining a price that‚Äôs hard to beat ahead of Black Friday weekend. If you want to push your graphical capability even further, a model is offered with the NVIDIA GeForce RTX 5060 for a $300 discount. That one normally goes for for $1,400, but has come down to just $1,100 in this early Black Friday deal.

See at Amazon



https://kotaku.com/alienware-aurora-16-gaming-laptop-with-rtx-5050-gpu-gets-cleared-out-at-an-all-time-low-for-black-friday-2000645928

item.title: Counter-Strike Pro Talks Sandwich Meme Sexism After Going Viral
item.content:encoded:
Day jobs are a reality for many pursuing their dreams. Artists, actors, musicians, and yes, even esports players often need to rely on income from elsewhere to fund their truest of passions. And one pro women‚Äôs Counter-Strike player recently went viral for sharing what she does to make ends meet: Making sandwiches.

Tilde Bystr√∂m, known as 7liciousCSGO in pro Counter-Strike spaces and with a reputation as both a highly accomplished player and commentator, shared a photo of her day job as a way to highlight the reality of what it means to not just play professional esports, but to do so as a woman (h/t Dexerto). This year, ESL Impact, a women‚Äôs pro CS2 circuit, ended after a three-year run citing an unsustainable economic model.

After 10 years in esports, I‚Äôm officially a sandwich maker üëç pic.twitter.com/G1TykLX6JS

‚Äî Tilde Bystr√∂m (@7liciousCSGO) November 19, 2025

Speaking to Dexerto, 7licious said that working a day job is nothing new, however. Referencing the fact that she has been told countless times by men that she should ‚Äúgo back to the kitchen‚Äù to make someone a sandwich,‚Äú she said, ‚ÄúI work by literally making sandwiches from 5-10 AM most mornings.‚Äù The post is ‚Äúa combination of a joke,‚Äù she said, ‚Äúbut at the same time, to be able to survive and pay rent and still play CS2, especially in the current state of the scene for women‚Äôs CS, I have to also work a normal job, and pretty much always had to have side jobs while pursuing my dream!‚Äù

And that dream includes a hope that the situation for women in esports improves, and that the barriers between men‚Äôs and women‚Äôs esports crumble. ‚ÄúThe dream for me,‚Äù Bystr√∂m said, ‚Äúis that women‚Äôs CS can evolve so much that we can, in the future, have mixed teams!‚Äù

The reality of having to essentially live two lives, one dedicated to a day job, the other to one‚Äôs true passions, isn‚Äôt easy to sustain. It‚Äôs bittersweet to see someone embrace the struggle of this lifestyle in stride while also recognizing the unfortunate economic and social realities that often prevent us from pursuing what matters most to us, especially for women.



https://kotaku.com/esl-impact-tilde-bystrom-7licious-csgo-cs2-2000646185
